sen.j: 義淵（ぎえん・ぎいん、生年不詳 － 神亀5年10月20日 (旧暦)（728年11月29日））は、奈良時代の法相宗の僧。
sen.e: GI En (aka GI In) (DOB? - Nov 29, 728) was a Hosso sect priest during the Nara period.

Gien (aka Giin; year of birth unknown - November 29, 728) was a priest of Hosso sect of Buddhism (Japanese equivalent of the Chinese Faxiang sect or Dharma-character school), who lived in the Nara period.
sen.cmt: 人名・形式・用語を修正しました。なお、対応wikiサイト上では、生年が「皇極天皇2年（643年）」と明記されています。こちらでは原文通りに不明としています。
sen.e: Gien (aka Giin; year of birth unknown - November 29, 728) was a priest of Hosso sect of Buddhism (Japanese equivalent of the Chinese Faxiang sect or Dharma-character school), who lived in the Nara period.

sen.j: 『続日本紀』によると俗性は市往氏であるが、『扶桑略記』では大和国高市郡の出身で阿刀氏とする。
sen.e: According to `Shoku Nihongi` (second of the six classical Japanese history texts) his lay clan name was `Ichiki` however, in the text `Fuso ryakki` (A Short History of Japan) he appears as born in Takaichi County in Yamato Province under the family name of `Ato`.

According to "Shoku Nihongi" (literally, Chronicle of Japan Continued, which is the second of the six classical Japanese history texts), his secular surname was Ichiki, but in "Fuso ryakki" (literally, A Short History of Japan) he appears as born in Takaichi no kori (or Takaichi-gun) County in Yamato Province under the clan name of Ato.
sen.cmt: 原文文頭の不要な句点を削除しました。形式・用語を修正しました。
sen.e: According to "Shoku Nihongi" (literally, Chronicle of Japan Continued, which is the second of the six classical Japanese history texts), his secular surname was Ichiki, but in "Fuso ryakki" (literally, A Short History of Japan) he appears as born in Takaichi no kori (or Takaichi-gun) County in Yamato Province under the clan name of Ato.

sen.j: 父母が長年観音菩薩に祈願して授かり、天武天皇により親王とともに岡本宮で養育されたという。
sen.e: For many years his parents prayed for a blessing before an image of the Kannon Buddhist deity of mercy and according to Emperor Tenmu he was raised along with the imperial princes at Okamoto palace.

It is said that for many years his parents had prayed for a blessing before an image of the Kannon Buddhist, deity of mercy, so that they were finally blessed with a baby who was Gien, and under Emperor Tenmu's command he was brought up along with the imperial princes at Okamoto no miya Palace.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ箇所を加筆修正し、表現・形式を修正しました。
sen.e: It is said that for many years his parents had prayed for a blessing before an image of the Kannon Buddhist, deity of mercy, so that they were finally blessed with a baby who was Gien, and under Emperor Tenmu's command he was brought up along with the imperial princes at Okamoto no miya Palace.

sen.j: 出家して元興寺に入り唯識・法相を修め、龍蓋寺（＝岡寺）などの5ヶ龍寺を創建した。
sen.e: He entered the priesthood at Ganko-ji temple where he studied vijnapti-matrata (theory that all existence is subjective and nothing exists outside of the mind) and the Hosso sect and established 5 branch temples.

He entered the Buddhist priesthood at Gango-ji Temple where he studied vijnapti-matrata or Consciousness-only school (aka Yuishiki or wei shih, i.e. a theory that all existence is subjective and nothing exists outside of the mind) and dharmalaksana or Dharma-character school (aka Hosso or faxiang, i.e. the specific characteristics of all manifest phenomena), and founded the gokaryu-ji (literally, the five Ryu [dragon] temples) including Ryugai-ji (aka Oka-dera) Temple.
sen.cmt: 用語・寺名の読み・表現を修正しました
sen.e: He entered the Buddhist priesthood at Gango-ji Temple where he studied vijnapti-matrata or Consciousness-only school (aka Yuishiki or wei shih, i.e. a theory that all existence is subjective and nothing exists outside of the mind) and dharmalaksana or Dharma-character school (aka Hosso or faxiang, i.e. the specific characteristics of all manifest phenomena), and founded the gokaryu-ji (literally, the five Ryu [dragon] temples) including Ryugai-ji (aka Oka-dera) Temple.

sen.j: 699年（文武天皇3年）学行褒賞で稲1万束を賜り、703年（大宝 (日本)3年）に僧正に任じられた。
sen.e: In 699 he received an religious studies academic prize of 10,000 sheaves of rice and in 703 was appointed as a high-priest.
In 699, he received an religious studies academic prize of 10,000 sheaves of rice and, in 703, was appointed as a sojo (high-priest).
sen.cmt: 形式・用語を修正しました
sen.e: In 699, he received an religious studies academic prize of 10,000 sheaves of rice and, in 703, was appointed as a sojo (high-priest).

sen.j: 元正天皇・聖武天皇両天皇の下で内裏に供奉した。
sen.e: Attended to Empress Gensho/Emperor Shomu at the imperial palace.
He attended to Empress Gensho and Emperor Shomu at the imperial palace as a naigubu (inner offerer which was any of the 10 high-ranking monks serving at the inner offering hall).
sen.cmt: 「内裏に供奉した」とは「内供奉として仕えた」と解釈して再訳出しました。参考：http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch/0/0na/16490613604800/
sen.e: He attended to Empress Gensho and Emperor Shomu at the imperial palace as a naigubu (inner offerer which was any of the 10 high-ranking monks serving at the inner offering hall).

sen.j: 『続日本紀』には、先代からの行いを称され727年（神亀4年）に岡連の姓を賜り兄弟に伝えることを許された、とある。
sen.e: in Shoku Nihongi (second of the six classical Japanese history texts) as with previous generations he was graciously permitted to serve his siblings in the Oka clan.

The "Shoku Nihongi" indicates that the Emperor extolled him for what he had done since the time of the previous emperor, he was granted the family name Oka no muraji and graciously permitted to share it with his siblings.
sen.cmt: 誤解釈箇所・用語・形式・表現を修正しました。なお、原文の記載内容の内、「兄弟に仕えること」（対応wikiサイト記載通り）とありましたが、意味不明につき調査しました結果、正しくは「兄弟に伝えること」と書かれていることが判明しました。続日本紀巻第十の該当箇所記載は「賜岡連姓。伝其兄弟。」です（http://www.j-texts.com/jodai/shoku10.html）ので、原文を修正のうえ再訳出しました。
sen.e: The "Shoku Nihongi" indicates that the Emperor extolled him for what he had done since the time of the previous emperor, he was granted the family name Oka no muraji and graciously permitted to share it with his siblings.

sen.j: 『三国仏法伝通縁起』によれば、弟子に玄ボウ・行基・隆尊・良弁などがおり、道慈・道鏡なども義淵の門下であったという。
sen.e: According to the text `Sangoku Buppo Denzu-engi` his pupils included Bo GEN/KI GYO/Son RYU/Ben RO etc and, it is said the DOJI and DOKYO etc were followers.

According to "Sangoku Buppo Denzu Engi" (literally, History of the transmission and propagation of Buddhism in the three countries), his pupils included Genbo, Gyoki, Ryuson and Roben, and it is further said that his followers included Doji and Dokyo.
sen.cmt: 用語・人名・表現を修正しました
sen.e: According to "Sangoku Buppo Denzu Engi" (literally, History of the transmission and propagation of Buddhism in the three countries), his pupils included Genbo, Gyoki, Ryuson and Roben, and it is further said that his followers included Doji and Dokyo.
